content: right
now that i'm playing warhammer i'm deep
in the mud of wanting to build my army i'm already buying more models than
i can keep up with painting in my spare time
and i keep finding third-party models that perfectly fit my legion of
nurgle demons this is a bit of a problem and it's made worse by the mandate i
gave myself of not being able to play with unpainted
models i don't want to get into the habit of
building models and letting myself play with them with just a coat of primer if
i do that i'm sure i'll fall into the trap of
never getting things painted so i needed to come up with a way to
realistically add painted models to my army at a
somewhat steady pace to do this i needed a painting plan that i could stick to
this goes against my nature as a creative person
i prefer to just wing things and let my builds have variety
i've never stuck to one method of stone painting or wood painting on terrain for
example but in this situation having some
guidelines and boundaries for painting is absolutely crucial so i created my
painting scheme after a bit of testing i found a painting method i liked and
refined it down as simply as i could when creating this plan i had four major
factors in mind the process had to be efficient i had to
be able to do it quickly and easily and it couldn't require steps that were
too complicated or easy to mess up the process also had to scale up and
down i wanted a plan that was practical for a unit of 10 to
20 models but also appropriate for a singular
character model it had to be easily replicated
i want the models that i might paint months apart to look cohesive and as if
they were painted at the same time and last they had to have a look that
was aesthetically pleasing i have a particular vibe and style that
i'm going for with my army and the paint scheme has to really sell
that vibe with a solid plan that meets all this
criteria i've set up a situation where i can bang out a paint job on a unit of
models almost as fast as i can assemble them
the great thing about creating this plan is that it removes a lot of the
guesswork the process won't be stunted by decision paralysis
and i won't be put off to start painting a model because i don't know what to do
i have a recipe and i can zone out and follow it and get the results that i
know i'm going to be happy with in the end
to demonstrate my paint job i'm going to be using this beautiful prototype model
from crippled god foundry who are the sponsors of this week's video
the model is one of many demon models that will be released in an upcoming
kickstarter crippled god makes beautiful resin cast models that i've used several
times before the casting quality is superb and always
a pleasure to work with plus they always have some really
creative sculpts soon they'll be launching a kickstarter
in order to release a massive set of more than 50 original sculpts inspired
by ancient greek lore as well as classic d d film and video
games the models are heroic 28 to 32
millimeter gaming scale and will be made available
as physical resin miniatures as well as stl files for at home printing
it seems a common complaint from people about miniature releases
is that they're either physical minis or downloadable files but rarely both
this campaign will solve that problem and you'll be able to pick whatever
works best for you if you print minis at home grab the
files and print out a horde of demons if you don't print yourself grab some of
the resin casts it's really awesome to see them offering
both options crippled god is a trusted company that has completed and fulfilled
successful kickstarters already so you can back with confidence and get
yourself all sorts of great demonic or heroic models for your tabletop rpgs or
even to use as unique proxies for wargaming
the kickstarter hasn't launched yet but i'll drop a link in the video
description where you can get more info and sign up to be alerted at launch time
an important part of my painting plan is basing the models before priming and
painting i find that while it can make things a
little harder to paint in terms of reaching certain areas
overall it's a lot more efficient if it's simple rank and file models
that's all they get but if it's a bigger character mini like this guy i like to
add some more details and elements i decided to go crazy with skulls on
this one for some reason i've been nursing the same box of citadel skulls
for years never letting myself use a ton of them on any one project
which is kind of silly since there's so many in a box and they really
aren't expensive so this big nurgle daddy got the full skull covered ground
treatment as well as a few broken space marine bits to really tie him into the
40k universe the texture paste plays one more
important role in creating a crusty nurgle look on my models
i like to use it sparingly on metal pieces to give a corroded texture
this is great on something like the keys of this model that are fairly smooth
a very thin coat of texture paste will add just a bit of grit that will make
them look ancient once painted because my paint scheme relies heavily
on under shading i primed the models in a xenothou
fashion first i hit everything with a very cheap
flat black primer and i followed that with a heavy
highlight of citadel wraith bone now in a lot of cases i'd advocate for
using a cheaper spray than the overpriced citadel stuff
the only reason i choose to go with this spray is because it has a very distinct
off-white color that i found for my test models gives a
slightly better look than if i were just to use an off-brand white but if i ever
find a flat bone color from my favorite cheap brand well i'd happily switch
the workhorse for this process are two specific contrast paints
i start with a coat of plague bearer flesh on all of the skin
now it's no surprise that this paint works really well for this as
it's clearly designed for this faction and named after them
on its own it actually creates a really nice serviceable look but the vibe i'm
after with my scheme is a little bit more sepia in nature so
i have a step in a moment that alters the tone significantly
before that step though i go in and paint all the metallics doing the
metallics at this stage is crucial for efficiency as all the
metal and the skin will receive the same coat
of contrast paint in the next step now for metallics i use only two vallejo
model air colors for anything that is iron i use the black metallic which is a
very dark kind of gunmetal and for the brass
and bronze which this particular model doesn't have
any on it i use a rust from the same line
which has a great bronze color next it's time for a coat of skeleton horde
contrast paint the combination of this rich sepia brown over top of the
green creates a sort of yellowish brown that's
a lot more dynamic and better suits what i personally think a nurgle
creature should look like what's interesting is that if you
reverse the order of application of these two paints you get a
slightly different but still coherent tone this is great for painting
something like plague drones where you want the plague bearer rider
to look slightly different than its mount but not too different
i found that skeleton horde contrast paint over the metallics also gives a
really wonderful grimy look with very little
effort
for all my nurgle demon eyes i use an orange
orange is my small secondary color for my entire death guard army i use it on
the eyes of the demons as well as any cloth on my plague marines
i base coat with a sort of rusty brown and highlight with a very
vibrant almost pumpkin orange now as good as these contrast paints look on
their own i do like to do a little bit of selective highlighting to kind of
accentuate some areas unfortunately i have yet to find an out
of the bottle color that perfectly works so i rely on mixing vallejo dead flesh
and moon yellow i do some larger highlights
with the mix and then a final small highlight with
just the yellow after that i paint out all the teeth
horns claws and sores with a kind of off-white bone
color given the amount of pimples and boils on
most nurgol models this is by far the most time consuming
part of the process but it's a step that's worth the time as
these little details are what give the model such a great look
i also hit any areas of open wounds with a bit of white to make the upcoming wash
really stand out in those areas i create a bit of a glaze using a mix of
skeleton horde and blood angel red contrast paint and i use
this to coat areas like the open mouths and wounds
the addition of the brown tone from the skeleton horde paint is crucial to
keeping my muted sepia tone color scheme and any horns
bones claws etc that are remaining are tinted
with a simple seraphim sepia wash on any metallics that are iron or steel i like
to apply a bit of a rusty wash sometimes i use this mission models rust
but i found that an appropriately colored acrylic ink
works just as well at this point i'll come back in with the same bone white
and do a very minimal highlight on things like teeth that may have become a
little too muted with the previous steps i decided early on to make my base
colors very simple again this is so that i could easily
replicate them they all get painted just black and then dry brushed with a bone
white and then washed with an egg wax earth
shade that's it nice and simple this combination also
means i don't need to do anything special or
different when the bases include things like bones or skulls
with the painting complete it's time to clear coat now i personally like
applying a satin varnish through an airbrush i
know a lot of people tend to gravitate towards a really matte clear coat but i
think a very slight shine is appropriate for these models
the last step is some gloss varnish applied with a brush to very specific
areas i put this on open mouths wounds eyes as well as all
the little clusters of pimples the tiny bit of gloss varnish on top of
those bright white boils that's what makes all the difference and
is one of my favorite parts of the whole scheme
in areas where there might be like guts hanging out or that i simply want to
look a little bit more gross i'll apply one more varnish that has
some blood red and skeleton horde contrast paint mixed
in and for maximum efficiency i'll do this with whatever gloss varnish is
still remaining in my palette from the previous step
now this paint scheme is not going to win any awards
but it is going to give me a realistic way to build a large army and create a
result that i'm absolutely proud to drop on any gaming
table like many paint schemes it will become
more and more impressive the more models you see together painted in the
same unified and cohesive style i think there are some small steps in
the process i can refine even further while not changing the look
like any recipe it will be perfected over time if you want to pick up any
tools or supplies to tackle your own army head over to blackmagiccraft.ca
there i've curated my essential equipment page that lists all the stuff
that i use and by doing your shopping through those
links well you help fund the production of videos like this
and if you get a lot of value out of these videos and you want to help me
keep making them consider supporting the channel on
patreon few bucks a month from viewers like you is why i'm able to put out a
video each and every week and i'd love to have you as the newest
member of the blackmagic craft fellowship
thanks for watching everyone let me know what you think in the comments section
share this video with your nergo loving friends and don't forget to check out
god's upcoming kickstarter cheers see you next week
you
